image.altText: Two men laughing

props.synopsis: Ibrahim Bazzi travelled to Lebanon to bring his wife back to Sydney to start a new life, while his brother Ali moved there to get married a few years ago.

title.children: Australian brothers killed in Lebanon after building hit by air strike, family says

image.altText: Lightning striking a boat.

props.synopsis: Severe storms across Australia's east coast have claimed the lives of nine people as the clean-up continues across several states.

title.children: Nine dead, including 9yo girl after Christmas and Boxing Day storms lash Australia's east coast

image.altText: Stephen Tait

props.synopsis: Family and friends are mourning the loss of seven people who have lost their lives during intense Christmas holiday storms in south-east Queensland.

title.children: 'One of the best': Victims remembered as seven killed in south-east Queensland storms

image.altText: Pat Cummins smiles on one knee

props.synopsis: The Boxing Day Test is in an interesting spot after a rain-affected day one, with Australia bowled out before lunch following an excellent Pakistan counterattack. Follow live.

title.children: Cummins strikes twice to halt Pakistan's resurgence on day two at MCG

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: BOWLED HIM! CUMMINS GETS BABAR WITH A BEAUTY!!
CUMMINS BREAKS THROUGH WITH A BLINDER!

image.altText: xiangqi

props.synopsis: The Chinese Xiangqi Association was also forced to address cheating rumours which involved the rhythmic use of a sex toy.

title.children: Chinese chess world rocked by cheating rumours, bad behaviour scandal

image.altText: Lee Sun-kyun wears dark winter clothes as he exits the front right side of a car and looks over his right shoulder.

props.synopsis: Lee Sun-kyun, who starred in the Oscar-winning film Parasite, is found unconscious in a car park while reportedly being investigated as part of a government crackdown on illegal drug use.

title.children: Parasite actor Lee Sun-kyun found dead in Seoul amid drug allegations

image.altText: A young woman sitting at a table with a bag of medications.

props.synopsis: Researchers say pollen is becoming more potent, and seasons longer, as the climate changes. Hay fever sufferers, brace yourselves.

title.children: The reason millions more Australians are expected to become hay fever sufferers

image.altText: A man with a beard and hat takes a selfie

props.synopsis: Four people have drowned at beaches across New South Wales since Christmas Day and one is missing in what has been described as the "deadliest time" of the year.

title.children: 19yo on holiday from Sydney still missing after trying to save brothers from rip as four drown across NSW

image.altText: Madi kneeling down next to Minka the staffy cross in front of a police truck.

props.synopsis: A woman who jumped into a fast-flowing river in Melbourne's south-west to save her dog has said she believes they were "very lucky" after they were rescued by police.

title.children: Woman who jumped into swollen river to save pet dog says she's 'very lucky' after emergency rescue

image.altText: A man smiling.

props.synopsis: Bill Granger has died in hospital in London, his family has announced. The renowned chef and food writer ran 19 restaurants around the world.

title.children: 'Bloody great guy': Celebrity chef Bill Granger remembered after Christmas Day death

image.altText: A yacht with a red and blue hull crashes through a wave

props.synopsis: Sydney to Hobart yacht race organisers say the contest remains too close to call as the leading yachts make their way down Tasmania's east coast, but the 2017 race record is looking safe.

title.children: 'It's anyone's race': Andoo Comanche increases lead in Sydney-Hobart yacht race

image.altText: A picture of a tennis match under lights on a court surrounded by a packed crowd in Melbourne.

props.synopsis: Reports suggest tennis authorities are considering an elite tour involving the four majors and top tournaments, in an attempt to ward off a LIV-style disruption of the sport — now two Australian tennis figures have had their say.

title.children: Aussie tennis veterans respond to reports of a new premium tour

image.altText: Salad dressing

props.synopsis: Most salad dressings are temporarily stable mixtures of oil and water known as emulsions. But how do salad dressing emulsions form? And how can we enhance our emulsions for better salads and more?

title.children: There's a science to the ideal salad dressing — and you can nail it at home

image.altText: An open black bag containing wrapped up packages of an illicit drug.

props.synopsis: More packages of cocaine have allegedly been discovered at beaches in Newcastle and the Central Coast, taking the total amount that has appeared on NSW beaches over the past week to 124kg.

title.children: More bricks of cocaine wash up on beaches between Sydney and Newcastle

image.altText: A woman wearing sunglasses smiles in front of the ocean with green hills in the distance

props.synopsis: Not everyone is satisfied with an office or working from home — they'd prefer to be operating from white-sand beaches and tropical rainforests. These Australians share the advantages and disadvantages of being a digital nomad.

title.children: These Australians work remotely while travelling overseas. But are they really living the dream?

image.altText: The dog tag of US Army Second Lieutenant Benjamin Cox.

props.synopsis: Dan O'Sullivan found a set of dog tags belonging to US Army Second Lieutenant Benjamin Cox in a Honiara market and, recognising their significance, began a 17-year quest to return them to his family.

title.children: Canberra paramedic completes 17-year quest to return WWII dog tags to US soldier's family

image.altText: A grey navy ship on the water with land in the background.

props.synopsis: Russia says two Ukrainian fighter jets were destroyed by anti-aircraft fire during the attack, however Ukraine has denied this claim.

title.children: Russia says naval ship in Crimea was damaged in air strike by Ukrainian forces

image.altText: An Israeli soldier rides in an armoured personnel carrier in Gaza.

props.synopsis: The Israeli defence minister says Lebanon, Syria, Iraq, and Yemen among possible locations in which actions have been taken.

title.children: Israel hints that it has struck international targets in retaliation

image.altText: A composite of two images: One of US President Joe Biden speaking in a suit and tie. The other of Donald Trump smiling in a suit

props.synopsis: Researchers say bogus claims will likely worsen during the next US election, as artificial intelligence becomes stronger and more accessible.

title.children: Experts warn of AI's impact on 2024 US election as deepfakes go mainstream and guardrails fade

image.altText: Side by side photos of Mary-Louise McLaws, Father Bob Maguire and Barry Humphries dressed as Dame Edna

props.synopsis: From master chefs and iconic artists to sporting legends and trailblazing politicians, Australia lost some of its most loved — and most controversial — icons this year.

title.children: Remembering the famous Australians who died this year

image.altText: A yellow airplane on a runway with the words spirit on it

props.synopsis: An American airline has publicly apologised after a six-year-old child ended up in the wrong city while travelling for the holidays.

title.children: 'Incorrectly boarded' 6yo ends up 260km away from family as US airline apologises

image.altText: Three women sit at a pool edge

props.synopsis: The migrant and refugee women learning to swim in this pool in regional New South Wales say attending the Armidale swim club is the highlight of their week. Here's why

title.children: For these Ezidi women, this swim club is so much more than just a dip in the pool

props.synopsis: Vet Michelle Noga moved from Sydney to regional NSW, and says living in a country town brings more than just career benefits.

title.children: 'Gunshot wounds, snake bites': The young women swapping city life to learn new skills as rural vets

image.altText: A montage of black and white images of 2 women and 2 men with an artist blue graphic design on top.

props.synopsis: Australia technically avoided a recession in 2023, though living standards went backwards for most of the population. Here's what four leading economists tip could happen in 2024.

title.children: Australia narrowly avoided recession this year. Here's what these experts think will happen in 2024

image.altText: An illustration in blue and pink colours shows a woman sitting alone in a room looking out a window

props.synopsis: Long COVID is not just destroying people's health. Behind closed doors, in homes across Australia and abroad, it is irreversibly changing relationships — sometimes for the better, too often for worse.

title.children: 'This is the end of the relationship': The marriages under strain from long COVID

image.altText: Two women smile in a close-up selfie.

props.synopsis: Susan Scardigno thanks the community for its support following her discharge from hospital, a week after she was seriously injured in an alleged stabbing attack which claimed the life of her colleague Julie Seed.

title.children: 'An amazing human': Woman discharged from hospital after alleged stabbing pays tribute to colleague

image.altText: A closeup of donald trump

props.synopsis: Colorado authorities are investigating possible threats against state Supreme Court justices, Denver police said on Tuesday, one week after the court's decision barring former President Donald Trump from the state's presidential primary ballot.

title.children: Denver police probe threats to Colorado judges in Trump ballot case

image.altText: A collage of colourful romance novels, most featuring cartoon illustrations of couples embracing.

props.synopsis: Readers are embracing romance novels with wild abandon and sending their favourite titles straight to number one. So we asked a bestselling romance author, publisher and bookseller why the genre is having such a moment.

title.children: The romance genre is 'blowing up' online. A bestselling author, publisher and bookseller explain why
